Demystifying Redux

Deepak Jayaram

VT Maple Script

0

Let's look at React..

  • UI = fn(State)
  • Components internally manage their state
  • As applications grow bigger, managing states shared across components becomes a chore
  • Confusing to know where a state should live

Simple Counter

 1. import React, { Component } from "react"
 2. 
 3. class ReactCounter extends Component {
 4.   
 5.   state = { 
 6.     counter: 0,
 7.     rotation: 0
 8.   };
 9. 
10.   incrementCounter = incrementValue => {
11.     this.setState(prevstate => ({
12.       counter: prevstate.counter + incrementValue,
13.       rotation: prevstate.rotation + 5
14.     }))
15.   }
16. 
17.   render() {
18.     return (
19.       <div>
20.         <button onClick={this.incrementCounter(1)}>
21.             +{this.props.incrementValue}
22.         </button>
23.         <div>
24.             <span>{this.state.counter}</span>
25.         </div>
26.       </div>
27.     )
28.   }
29. }
30. 
31. export default ReactCounter

overview

Enter Flux

  • Application architecture that Facebook uses for building client-side web applications
  • Utilizes a unidirectional data flow
  • Dispatcher -> Store -> Controller Views -> View

Single source of truth

Single Source of Truth

 1. console.log(store.getState())
 2. 
 3. // Prints
 4. {
 5.   visibilityFilter: 'SHOW_ALL',
 6.   todos: [
 7.     {
 8.       text: 'Thank you for coming to my LevelUP session',
 9.       completed: true,
10.     },
11.     {
12.       text: 'Stay Awesome',
13.       completed: true
14.     }
15.   ]
16. }

overview

State is read-only

Actions

 1. store.dispatch({
 2.   type: 'SET_STATE_LOCKED',
 3.   index: true
 4. })
 5. 
 6. store.dispatch({
 7.   type: 'SET_AWESOMENESS_LEVEL',
 8.   payload: '100%'
 9. })

overview

Action Creators

function addTodo(text) {
  return {
    type: ADD_TODO,
    text
  }
}
function toggleTodo(index) {
  return { 
      type: TOGGLE_TODO, 
      payload: index 
    }
}

Functions that create actions   🤷

Changes are made with pure functions

Pure vs Impure Functions

 1. // Pure functions
 2. function square(x) {
 3.   return x * x;
 4. }
 5. 
 6. function squareAll(items) {
 7.   return items.map(square);
 8. }
 9. 
10. // Impure functions
11. function square(x) {
12.   updateXInDatabase(x);
13.   return x * x;
14. }
15. 
16. function squareAll(items) {
17.   for (let i = 0; i < items.length; i++) {
18.     items[i] = square(items[i]);
19.   }
20. }

overview

Reducers

  • function(previousState, action) => newState
  • "Given a set of inputs, it should always return the same output. No surprises, No side effects. No API calls. No mutations"
  • Writing clean reducers result in code that is easy to maintain, test and debug

Reducers

 1. function todoReducer(state = initialState, action) {
 2.   switch(action.type) {
 3.     case 'INCREMENT':
 4.       return {
 5.         ...state,
 6.         count: state.count + 1
 7.       };
 8.     case 'DECREMENT':
 9.       return {
10.         ...state,
11.         count: state.count - 1
12.       };
13.     default:
14.       return state;
15.   }
16. }

overview

  • The state of your application is stored in a single object - Single source of truth
  • Actions are plain objects & Action creators create actions
  • You cannot modify state directly, you've got to create an action - State is read-only
  • Pure Functions are functions that have a predictable outcome
  • Changes to the state are made using Reducers - which are pure functions
